Attending: Dr. Lisa Chang, MD

INDICATION: Recurrent right malignant pleural effusion (lung adenocarcinoma, EGFR+). Prior thoracenteses x 4. Patient prefers pleurodesis over IPC.

PROCEDURE: 
1. Medical thoracoscopy (pleuroscopy)
2. Pleural biopsy
3. Talc poudrage pleurodesis
4. Chest tube placement

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation with local anesthesia

PROCEDURE: Patient in left lateral decubitus. Entry via 7th ICS mid-axillary line. 1000mL serous fluid drained. Thoracoscope (LTF-160) introduced. Findings:
- Parietal pleura: Diffuse nodular studding, largest 5mm
- Visceral pleura: Scattered nodules
- Diaphragm: Nodular implants
- Lung: Partially trapped, ~70% expansion achievable

Multiple biopsies taken from parietal and diaphragmatic pleura using flexible forceps (8 specimens total).

After fluid evacuation and lung re-expansion to ~80%, talc poudrage performed (4g sterile talc via atomizer, even distribution). 24Fr chest tube placed, connected to suction (-20cmH2O).

SPECIMENS: Pleural biopsies x 8, pleural fluid (cytology, cell block)
COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: Minimal
DISPOSITION: Admit for chest tube management. Target removal in 48-72hr if output <150mL/day and lung expanded.

Dr. Lisa Chang, MD
